This comes in addition to a grant of £, from the Scottish Government Regeneration Capital Grant Fund awarded in February and £, from the Robertson Trust.Together, these funders have provided MACPool with  per cent of the capital build costs of the project, with applications for the remaining  per cent well advanced.The lottery funding means that the group overseeing the project, Mid Argyll Community Enterprises Ltd, can brief architects and move closer to the construction stage without further delay.Kim Ritchie, chair of the MACPool board said: #This is such exciting news, not just for MACPool but for the entire community of Mid Argyll.#We are so grateful to the National Lottery Community Fund, the Regeneration Capital Grant Fund – and to Argyll and Bute Council, which sponsored our application – and to the Robertson Trust for this major investment in our future.#We can’t wait to get started.#The redeveloped MACPool will feature:Building work is scheduled to start in January .The capital build cost is, however, not the whole story and funding applications still need to be submitted for fit-out and revenue costs – though £, of these have already been secured from the Co-op Communities Fund and FCC Scottish Action Fund.Mrs Ritchie added: #It wouldn’t be a community pool without the opportunity for members of the community to contribute, so watch this space to see how you can be involved in building the future of your pool.#

title: the time is now in argyll and bute
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsArgyll is leading the way amid a push for a greener, fairer post-coronavirus future, led by young people from Mid Argyll.Amid the personal and economic tragedy, there are growing calls to use the global shock as an opportunity to build a better society # and tackle climate change.A recent report to the UK government by independent Climate Change Committee urged Ministers to seize the opportunity to turn the COVID- crisis into a defining moment in the fight against climate change.The Climate Coalition campaign group, however, wants to push that bit harder and last week urged supporters to lobby MPs as part of #The Time is Now# campaign to put people, climate and nature at the heart of the UK’s recovery from coronavirus.During a meeting co-ordinated by Tayvallich brother and sister Rowan and Freya Aitchison, Argyll and Bute MP Brendan O#Hara was duly quizzed on the issue by a group of around  constituents from Mid Argyll, Cowal and Helensburgh # the Argyll and Bute Climate Change Group.Among the matters discussed were the five key priorities recommended by the Climate Change Committee: Low-carbon retrofits and buildings that are fit for the future tree planting, peatland restoration, and green infrastructure strengthening of energy networks infrastructure to make it easy for people to walk, cycle, and work remotely and moving towards a circular economy through recycling.Mr O#Hara said during the online discussion on Wednesday July  that he acknowledges that the pandemic gives us an opportunity to rethink the way that we live.Speaking afterwards, he added: #I have always believed that politics is at its best when it is organised locally, by people who share a passion and want to effect real change. The Argyll and Bute Climate Change group challenged me to make sure that I didn’t get into the habit of seeing this as a single issue but rather one that impacts absolutely everything I do at Westminster, from economic recovery planning, to defence and security, human rights and international affairs.#If there is a silver lining to this awful COVID- pandemic it is that going forward, we can do things dferently as iniduals, as a country, internationally and of course, globally. And its an opportunity we must take.#Mr O#Hara referenced the group and their meeting on the floor of the House of Commons the following day, when he asked the Secretary of State for Transport about the group#s dismay that #once again the UK Government had missed almost every one of on its emissions targets#.#We are very fortunate that our MP Brendan O’Hara understands the urgency of the climate crisis, and is open to some of our suggestions,# said -year-old Rowan Aitchison.He continued: #We desperately need to retire GDP as a measure of our wellbeing and work towards a system that allows people to live a fulfilling le. Scotland is one of very few countries that have made a start on this, pioneering a government system which is based on a wellbeing economy. We need to accept that money is not the key to human happiness, and start putting our wellbeing before increasing our profit margins.#

title: argyllshire advertiser leader column july 10 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsPeople remarked on the freshness of the air. Others noticed birdsong. Some even thought the sky had become bluer. Wildle appeared in places formerly too crowded with people to venture into during daylight.Remember the start of lockdown  Cars, buses, lorries and planes suddenly vanished almost completely and we seemed to see the environment improving before our eyes.Our imagination could have been at work, but there were also statistics showing a rapid drop in pollution around cities during lockdown # so perhaps there was something in it.Which is why we really owe it to ourselves, our descendants and every living thing to try to change the way we live.And before we start any what-aboutery , we need to start somewhere and each do our wee bit.That could be as simple as buying local, supporting local food and drink producers and thinking about plastic usage.More power to the elbow of the young people of Mid Argyll driving the agenda and bending the ears of politicians.Let#s hope they are listening.

title: selkirk-rugby-players-bid-clean-town
story: HAVING just completed a sponsored charity project that raised almost pound, in under a fortnight for the townrsquos foodbank, Selkirk Rugby Clubrsquos players arenrsquot letting the grass grow under their feet.This week members of the clubrsquos playing squad have embarked on yet another lsquochallengersquo to support the local community ndash litter collection.The idea came from former st XV skipper Ross Nixon, and comes in the wake of a similar venture undertaken by Glasgow Warriorsrsquo professional players.ldquoWhen yoursquore walking in and around Selkirk, you canrsquot help noticing pieces of litter that have been left lying around, often when proper bins arenrsquot that far away, said Nixon.ldquoI thought it would be a good idea for Selkirk players to take a bin bag with them when they head out to take their daily exercise, picking up any litter they see next to paths or along roadside verges.ldquoWersquore lucky in Selkirk to have such unspoilt countryside to exercise in, so itrsquos a shame to see it spoiled by discarded empty bottles, food wrappers and general rubbish.ldquoI kicked off the campaign by nominating three members of our players ndash Aaron McColm, Ewan MacDougall and Liam Cassidy ndash to collect litter on their walks.ldquoEach of this trio will then challenge a further three players to collect litter, and in turn these three will nominate other team-mates, and so on.The project has the backing of Selkirk head coach Scott Wight.He said: ldquoItrsquos another way the club can put something back into the local community, though this time therersquos no sponsorship involved.ldquoItrsquos looking asitrsquos going to be a wee while before any rugby is going to be played, so this latest effort not only helps keep the players in touch with each other, itrsquos also providing a useful service for the Selkirk community.Meanwhile, Selkirk Rugby Club is to stage its annual Players Presentation Night on Fridayndash although this yearrsquos event will be a lsquovirtualrsquo get-together.The plan is for the clubrsquos coaches, players and rugby officials to be digitally linked via Zoom, with Selkirk head coach Scott Wight be given by, among others, the clubrsquos chairman and its director of rugby, as well as recaps of the st and lsquoArsquo XVsrsquo seasons by the sidesrsquo respective team managers."It should be a fun evening!

title: rugby-players-hailed-helping-prepare-golf-course

title: face-coverings-mandatory-scotlands-shops---rules-exempt
story: FACE coverings will become mandatory in Scotlands shops from the end of next week, the First Minister has confirmed.During her daily briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said the Scottish Government has been considering the issue of face coverings "for some time now".She confirmed it will become mandatory in Phase .Why the change Face coverings became mandatory in Scotland on all public transport on June .The First Minister said: "As we all start to interact more, it is vital that we take all reasonable steps to reduce risk."And we know that these coveringscan help reduce the risk of transmission indoors."She added: "This is a really important wayfor all of us to help protect each other and to display that sense of solidarity that has served us well."When does it become mandatory Ms Sturgeon said the enforcement will take place on Phase  - July .However sheurged Scots not to wait until next week, asking them to get into the habit now.How will it be enforced The First Minister said the rules will be enforced in a similar way to those on public transport.She said it would be "not fair or reasonable" to expect shop workers to enforce the rules - and instead it would be down to the police to do so.Fixed penalty notices - which start at pound - could be handed out by the police, but she says they will do so only asa last resort.Ms Sturgeon added: "All of us can help by doing this voluntarily because it can make a dference".Who is exempt Children under five will be exempt from this rule, Ms Sturgeon confirmed, along with those with certain medical conditions.Following in line with the public transport rules, then the following groups may also be exempt:Police officers first responders in an emergencyStaff separate by a physical barrier ndash including bus drivers behind a screenAnyone with ahealthcondition where a mask would cause dficulty, including asthmaYou need to take medicationTo speak with someone who lip readsWhen asked to remove it by a relevant authority, e.g. Police officer.But Ms Sturgeonsaid: ldquoFor everyone , face coverings will be mandatory."What  was announced MsSturgeon also announced that the two-metre social distancing rule can be reduced in the hospitality and retail sectors and on public transport at that time.Pubs, restaurants and shops will be allowed to adhere to a one-metre rule instead, with mitigation measures in place.But the general rule in law will be that businesses must take reasonable measures to ensure two-metre distancing is maintained, she said.The First Minister also said , patients have now died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up by one from , on Wednesday.A total of , people have tested positive for the virus, up by five from , the previous day.

title: air-bridges-apply-scotland-can-go-holiday-abroad
story: HOLIDAYMAKERS from England can embark on overseas trips from next Friday as quarantine restrictions are lted ndash but not people from Scotland.The current -day isolation policy for peopleto or visiting Scotland remains in place for now, the Scottish Government has confirmed, despite the restrictions being eased south of the border.As it stands, people from England will be able to travel to destinations such as Spain, France, Italy and Germany.A full list of countries which the UK Government regards as posing aldquoreduced risk of Covid- will be published later today, and could feature as many as  nations.However, there is still a chance that travellers from the UK will have to self-isolate on arrival into some of the other states.The blanket guide against all but essential travel will also be changed tomorrow.What is an air bridge An air bridge, also known as a travel corridor, will allow tourists to travel between two countries without the need to quarantine.The agreements between countries, particularly those with low cases ofcoronavirus, allow two-way travel without restrictions.Do air bridges apply to Scotland The First Minister has criticised the UK Government for failing to consult the devolved administration before announcing the proposed changes.The Scottish Government says a four-nations agreement hasnot yet been reached.A spokesman said the UK Government is lting quarantine restrictions for countries ldquowhich present dfering levels of risk.ldquoIt is disappointing that the UK Government have chosen to make an announcement on the countries they intend to exempt before a four nations agreement has been reached, he said.ldquoWe would still like to reach a four nations approachpossible, but that is dficult when the UK Government change proposals and give us last-minute sight of them.While border controls remains a reserved matter, the issue of health is devolved ndash therefore allowing the Scottish Government to retain control over quarantine measures in this country.This means, as it stands, the current restrictions remain in place in Scotland for now.Could this change Speaking on Monday, the First Minister said she wanted to ldquotake a bit of time to consider the public health impact of removing the -day quarantine.She added she wanted to look at the evidence underpinning the decision south of the border and would feed back as soon as possible.What are the quarantine rules in Scotland The following measures were put in place from June :Residents and visitors arriving from abroad must self-isolate for  daysAll travellers must complete an online passenger locator form supplying contact details, travel details and the address of where they will self-isolateBorder Force will carry out spot checks at the border and can impose a fine of pound on those who refuse to comply.Arrangements will be made for those arriving into Scotland to be contacted during self-isolation to receive public health advice and informationThose who fail to self-isolate can be fined pound.Persistent offenders can be reported to the procurator fiscal for potential prosecution and a maximum pound, fine.

title: borders-rugby-pitch-become-beer-garden-plans
story: BORDERS revellers have snapped up every ticket for a ldquobeer garden event at Hawick rugby clubrsquos ground.The club plans to host drinkers on the Mansfield Park pitch at a series of events, starting on July .Talks with Scottish Borders Counciland the police are continuing today .A joint statement from the club and SBC reads: ldquoBoth the club and the council are hopeful that the planned event on Saturday, July , which has already been fully booked, will be able to take place, subject to all public health matters being resolved and the necessary licence being approved.Beer gardens in Scotland are allowed to open from Mondayas lockdown restrictions continue to be eased.This is the full statement issued on Thursday, July "Hawick Rugby Football Club and Scottish Borders Council would like to confirm that they continue to work together with a view to the club holding lsquobeer gardenrsquo events on the pitch."The club requires an occasional licence for these events to take place and has submitted an application today to Scottish Borders Council."A Safety Advisory Group meeting involving the club, Council and other relevant partners, including Police Scotland, will take place tomorrow to enable detailed discussions to take place on all necessary matters, including public health."In light of this, the club is reviewing its plans for events currently scheduled for the early part of next week."Both the club and the Council are hopeful that the planned event on Saturday  July, which has already been fully booked, will be able to take place, subject to all public health matters being resolved and the necessary licence being approved."

title: borders-book-festival-2020-line-up-revealed-july-talks
story: AN online version of the Borders Book Festival begins this month.Festival co-director Paula Ogilvie says ldquothe skyrsquos the limit for the series of talks, which kick off on July  and run every Sunday for  weeks.Stalwarts, including Rory Bremner and James Naughtie, will be back to entertain fans in the pre-recorded sessions.But they will also be joined by new names including YouTube chef Suzanne Mulholland ndash aka The Batch Lady ndash and childrenrsquos author Chris Lloyd.After each talk plays out live, authors will be available to answer questions at the end.The series has been organised because of the cancellation of the physical festival, which had been due to be held in June at Harmony House, Melrose.ldquoWe thought it was quite an important thing to do, said Mrs Ogilvie, on the idea of a virtual version.ldquoItrsquos not a perfect experience and we canrsquot replicate the real event, but at least the author is still there and still interacting with the audience.While audiences wonrsquot be sitting ldquoshoulder to shoulder and seeing the whites of the authorsrsquo eyes, it does mean more people will be able to join the festival, albeit virtually.Mrs Ogilvie said: ldquoWersquove got festival goers who now live in far flung places."We had a bit of response with people saying, lsquoI live in Canada now, I was really missing the festival but I can be part of it ndash I can watch it.rsquo So therersquos a good up side to it.The festival will also be able to talk to authors on the other side of the world.ldquoFor the August programme, wersquove got some names that are not based in the UK, said Mrs Ogilvie.ldquoThis allows us to have authors and thinkers who ordinarily wersquod have a bit of a challenge to get to the UK, never mind the Scottish Borders.But launch day will see one guest who is always happy toto the Borders ndash festival favourite Rory Bremner, in conversation with festival founder Alistair Moffat.ldquoRory Bremner is a real stalwart of the festival, said Mrs Ogilvie.ldquoHersquos been with us since , he appears every year and has also helped us to shape the programme.ldquoHersquoll do what Rory does ndash therersquoll be impersonations, and a lot of chat about the last  or so years that hersquos been involved in the festival and the highlights from that, so thatrsquoll be fun.Also appearing on July , in the pm slot, is internet sensation Suzanne Mulholland, aka The Batch Lady.The Batch Lady, whose book of the same name is out now, has garnered , followers on her YouTube, Instagram and Facebook channels. She has also appeared in Hellomagazine, the Daily Mailand The Sun.ldquoShersquos quite a phenomenon, said Mrs Ogilvie. ldquoShersquos already super popular but is gathering more momentum and I love the fact shersquos based in the Scottish Borders.,params: .pushldquoFor her event with us shersquoll talk about her book, but also do a -minute demonstration with a number of dferent recipes from the book.Other highlights of the July programme include journalist and broadcaster Kirsty Wark in conversation with former Vogueeditor Alexandra Shulman, and an evening with award-winning crime writers Mark Billingham and Chris Brookmyre.Moving the -year-old book festival online might have been a ldquosteep learning curve, according to Mrs Ogilvie, but it has also been essential to keep the event alive, and books and authors in the limelight.ldquoIt just means we can start to shine even more of a light on the Scottish Borders and our authors and what the festival does, said Mrs Ogilvie. ldquoThe skyrsquos the limit.Borders Book Festivals July programmeJuly am: Make Your Own Rockpool Book with Jill Calderpm: The Batch Ladypm: Rory Bremner in conversation with Alistair MoffatJuly am: Joseph Coelho  Fiona Lumbers: Luna Loves Artpm: Alexandra Shulman in conversation with Kirsty Warkpm: James NaughtieJuly am: Humanimal ndash Incredible Ways Animals are Just Like Us! with Chris Lloydpm: Paul Murton in conversation with Alistair Moffatpm: Mark Billingham in conversation with Chris BrookmyreAuthor names for August and September will be released at a later date.For more information, go to the Borders Book Festival website.

title: face-masks-buy-face-coverings-independent-stores-scotland
story: Face coverings are to become mandatory in Scotlands shops from July , First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has announced.The new rule comes just two weeks after passengers on public transport were told they must cover their faces when travelling.Some Scots across the country have already been practising the habit of wearing face masks when out in public, but as covering up becomes a legal requirement, many of us are now in the market for a quality face mask.Of course, major fashion brands such as ASOS, Boohoo and River Island were quick to get in on the action and are selling masks online.Butindependent and Scottish-made masks are more your style, here is our rundown of where in Scotland is selling the worldrsquos latest hot commodity.BroraWith Scottish cashmere at its heart, luxury clothing brand Brora began producing face masks for both adults and children from the surplus material at one of their Portuguese factories making PPE.Edinburgh store manager Sophie Hopkinson said: ldquoWe really wanted to come up with a great idea to give back, so pound from every mask will go to NHS charities and other small charities.ldquoThey are really nice to wear since theyrsquore a natural fibre, and ever since we opened theyrsquove been incredibly popular."Breathe EasyWhen the pandemic hit, engineer and entrepreneur Gavin McAdam got to work creating masks.His Edinburgh-based start-up Breathe Easy began by asking only for donations to try and help the third-party care sector and vulnerable groups get access to quality medical-grade face masks.And when someone got in touch askingMr McAdam could create a face mask for their deaf son, the company set about creating and trialling a cotton face mask with a transparent plastic face .Now Breathe Easy continues to issue free face masks to a iety of charities around Scotland, but also sells both full cotton masks and those with transparent  for deaf and hard of hearing communities on their website.Owner Gavin McAdam said: ldquoWersquore growing all the time and employing more people to keep up with demand.ldquoWersquore also working in partnership with the National Manufacturing Institute and Glasgow University in the development of a novel material that has natural microbial properties, engineered to capture the exact particle size of the Covid- virus."We will be trialling the first of these masks in two or three weeks."Slanj KiltsSlanj Kilts recently came into the limelight when Nicola Sturgeon was seen wearing one of their latest wares.The First Minister was spotted modelling the homeless tartan design, which sees % of all its sales donated to Shelter.General Manager Ross Lyall said: ldquoWe started making face masks in February in anticipation of lockdown. Sales were trickling through, but then of course Nicola wore our mask, and it went mental.ldquoThe traditional kilt business is dependent on the wedding industry, so we were very worried about the way things are at the moment and asking ourselves where the money is going to come fromthere are no weddings.ldquoSuddenly we had thousands of orders going through, so we are currently trying to recruit as many sowers as possible to keep up with demand.Mischke LingerieAs an Aberdeen-based brand known for its lingerie, this company is now also producing cloth masks in a iety of dferent colours and prints, with a pocket for a filter, for only pound..Designer Hazel Lethaby, founder of Mischke Lingerie said:"We have a passion for making small and beautul things and firmly believe that the Devil is in the detail."I started making masks as I saw a need to use my skills to produce something for the general public so that there was no need for people to buy up supplies of medical grade equipment."The masks I make are not designed as PPE but can be worn to comply with the guidelines in stores and on public transport."I am using mainly % cotton gingham as it has a stylish and playful look and its easy to wash, making the masks more sustainable. The design is also zero waste, there are no offcuts!"Mirka Bridal CoutureOwner of this Kirkcaldybridal store Mirka Jankowska has been hard at workcollaboratingwith Laila Letteringto produce limited edition face masks during lockdown.,params: .pushFor each face mask purchase Mirka Bridal Couture are donatinga face mask to the Childrenrsquos Oncology Ward in Edinburgh who are in need of reusable face masks for their young patients and their families.Julie Macintyre Handmade Bags Julie Macintyre, from Dalkeithnear Edinburgh,has pressed pause on making bags to create beautul Harris Tweed face masks.After trialling several designsshe found that the above product, with % cotton lining, was most comfortable to wear.Handmade by DotThis independent store has added face masks to its list of handmade items, which already includes bottle light lamps, hand-knitted items, handmade cards, and jewellery.The face masks come in a wide range of colours and patterns, are washable and double lined with a filter pocket.

title: tescos-major-changes-shopping-online
story: Tesco has confirmed a big change for people who regularly shop online and use their home delivery service.The retailer saysa feature that was previously suspended - due to coronavirus - has now ed.What is the change for online shoppers Tescos Delivery Saver plan - which stopped back in April - resumed on Wednesday, July .The supermarket giant says themove will make it easier for their most loyal customers to easily picka delivery slot.In an email to shoppers, Tesco said: "As you know, we suspended Delivery Saver payments in April, which allowed us to support , vulnerable customers with .million orders."We couldnt have done this without your patience and understanding."Wersquore now planning to restart Delivery Saver plans from  July."What  has changed Tesco has also updated themaximum item restriction for deliveries.When lockdown began in March, orders were limited to a maximum item number of .Now, the limit has been increased to amaximum of  items.What is theTesco Delivery Saver plan Delivery Saver is Tescos subscription-based delivery service, which is designed to help shoppers reduce the cost of home deliveries for their grocery orders.The plans come with a iety of benefits, according to Tesco.These include:Free delivery onshopping across all of Tescos online departments.If shoppers spend more on a plan than they would have done on deliveries, the retailer will email them an eCouponwith the dference -within  days of their plan ending.Customers will also earn points on every Delivery Saver payment, as well as collecting points on their shopping.Online shoppers will also be able to getearly access for delivery slots at Christmas and Easter.

title: borders-trader-a-true-champion-local-businesses
story: A BORDERS businessman has been hailed as a high street legend for promoting fellow traders in his town.Shop owners and locals have heaped praise on Ian McFadyen for his community spirit, calling him ldquoan ambassador for Peebles.Ian, who owns the House of Gaia with his we Paula, often closes the doors to his High Street shop to operate a live video feed.Streaming through his social media page, he gives details on every business in the town and tells his audience what they have to offer.Cafeacute owners Della Murray and Artur Budenko told the Border : ldquoIan is a real advocate for the High Street and surrounding areas."A true champion of local businesses. Full credit must be given to him for all that he does for us.Ian and Paula are the proprietors of a mind body and spirit shop, which boasts one of the largest selections of crystals in Scotland.The couple recently helped NHS hospitals create chill-out zones for stressed medical staff fighting the coronavirus.They donated goods to the Borders General Hospital, Edinburgh Royal Infirmary, and Hay Lodge Community Hospital.Their High Street shop is now back open and we caught up with Ian to ask how the first day went.ldquoIt was fantastic ndash we had a full shop throughout most of the day, he said."We had people posting on Facebook saying that they wanted to come to the shop."A family who lived in Peebles, and have now moved to Edinburgh, came down specically for the shop opening ndash which was great.ldquoPeople have been super respectful of each other, social distancing and staying safe."There is a massive dference in the High Street and the atmosphere as the connections are being made again.ldquoAs a community wersquore a community of shopkeepers as well. When we see services like Coltmanrsquos Restaurant close and then reopen again, itrsquos fantastic."Nobody is going to come to Peebles for one shop ndash we need dferent services.ldquoIrsquom new to retail and I had no idea how dficult it would be. The glory days of retail on the High Street are gone so itrsquos very hand to mouth with people.ldquoWhen I see people opening their doors, or not able to open their doors, or struggling to purchase new stock or new lines, I feel that."I feel exactly what every other shopkeeper or business has in the High Street.A humble man, Ian is quick to praise other businesses for their efforts through the lockdown.ldquoI look at shops like Scott Brothers which has been servicing the community for years."Irsquove been in Peebles on and off for  years and since the day I first came here that shop has been open."Theyrsquove had to deal with massive changes in retail, like big multinationals like BQ and Screwfix coming in and really affecting their business."Yet throughout the lockdown they were open and servicing their local community and that needs to be recognised.True to form, the day after reopening, Ian popped a lsquoBack in  minutes sign on his shop door.He proceeded along the High Street giving a shout-out to his neighbouring retailers and businesses in a live vlog, to which one viewer wrote: ldquoYoursquore a Peebles legend.

title: support-scottish-independence-jumped-says-poll
story: SUPPORT for Scottish independence has risen markedly, according to a new poll.A Panelbase poll for The Sunday Timesfound that  per cent backed the lsquoyesrsquo side.The result reflects a five-point rise in support for independence since the last such poll in March, alongside a five-point fall for the unionist side.The poll of , voters in Scotland was conducted between Tuesday and Friday.According to The Sunday Times, politics professor John Curtice believes First Minister Nicola Sturgeonrsquos handling of the coronavirus pandemic has helped to boostthe cause of independence.He said: ldquoNever before have the foundations of public support for the union looked so weak.ldquoUnsurprisingly, for many nationalists, the past three months have exemplied how Scotland could govern itself better as an independent, small country.ldquoMore importantly, it may have persuaded some former unionists of that claim, too.

title: sam-heughan-scottish-actor-tipped-fans-next-james-bond

title: first-pint-english-pubs-reopened
story: Border reporter Callum Hodgson has been staying in his native north-east during lockdown. On Saturday, he went out for a pint to mark the reopening of Englands pubs...I DONrsquoT think I have ever been in two minds about going to the pub.And I never thought I would ever have to write a piece explaining what it is like to go for a drink in one.But lockdown has made people anxious.So, as I have been working in England for the past three months, we thought you might like to know what measures pubs are taking south of the border ndash as Scotland prepares to reopen.I thought it would be best to pick one I know well ndash my lsquolocalrsquo, the one I have frequented since legally allowed to do so.But this time it was a stranger experience.This time I actually had to book in advance to make sure I could get in on lsquoSuper Saturdayrsquo.And on arrival punters were told to use hand sanitiser gel, which was provided.At the door I was greeted by the lsquohostrsquo who showed me to my allocated seat.You were not able to move to another area and the only need to stand up was to go to the bar or to the toilet.A sheet of paper was given so you could write down your name and contact details ndash just in case you need to be traced in the future. That can make you feel slightly uneasy.Perspex screens have been installed at the counter and several urinals and toilet stalls were marked out of order.And there was no entertainment ndash no jukebox, no pool table and no darts.The pubrsquos  tables were placed at least two metres apart ndash so there was no need to come into contact with anybody .When buying a drink, you had to follow a one-way system around the bar and there was a contactless card machine although you could still use cash.Overall, I would say the pub I visited took all the necessary steps to make it as safe as possible.There was no overcrowding and everyone stuck to the rules until closing time ndash which was at pm.Would I visit again  Yes. My namersquos in the book for the same table at the same time next week.I am sure there will be places which are not as organised as mypub.But my experience was a dferent, but positive one.I may, however, take a dferent viewI receive a phone call.

title: beautiful-national-trust-scotland-tourist-spots-reopening-today
story: DAY-TRIPPERS across Scotland can rejoice as dozens of tourist hotspots reopen for the first time since lockdown.The National Trust for Scotland has announced outdoor sites across the country will be able to welcome visitors as of today.It comes following changes to lockdown measures from the Scottish Government, which allows people to travel further than five miles for leisure - with exceptions in place in parts of Dumfries and Galloway.Of the sites opening today, two will only open with timed entry to manage numbers and maintain safe physical distancing ndash Culzean Country Park in Ayrshire and Threave Garden in Dumfries and Galloway.More than , slots have already been pre-booked in the first few days of Culzean tickets being made available online.It comes after the charity said some indoor facilities may not reopen until the   season including Bannockburn Visitor Centre, Hill of Tarvit, House of the Binns, Kippen Smiddy, Leith Hall, Holmwood and Souter Johnniersquos Cottage.The charity has also warned residents within the local lockdown in parts of Dumfries and Galloway ldquonot to travel to its propertiesit entails a journey beyond the five-mile limit.Threave House and Garden in Dumfries  GallowaySome sites will have takeaway food and drink on offer but visitors are reminded to take litter home with them and toilet facilities will also be in place ndash though not at all properties.The full list of sites reopening today :Aberdeenshirendash Castle Fraser, Crathes Castle, Drum Castle, Fyvie Castle, Haddo House, Leith HallCraigie Castle, PitmeddenMar Lodge Estate .Angusndash Barry MillHouse of Dun .Argyllndash Arduaine Garden Crarae Garden Geilston Garden .Ayrshire and Arranndash Brodick Country Park, Culzean Country Park .Dumfries and Gallowayndash Threave .Edinburgh and Lothiansndash Inveresk Lodge GardenMalleny Garden.Fendash Culross PalaceFalkland PalaceKellie Castle .Glasgowndash Greenbank Garden .Highlandsndash Brodie Castle, InvereweCulloden .Perthshirendash Branklyn Garden.Scottish Bordersndash Harmony Garden, Priorwood Garden.Phil Long, the charityrsquos new chief executive, said: ldquoItrsquos wonderful news that been seeing for myself the incredible work that has been done to get ready for visitors once again.,params: .pushldquoSadly, we canrsquot yet bring people inside the castles, houses and visitor Right now, we should be in the midst of our busiest period, with visitors from home and abroad ing to and discovering for the first time the magical places that we look after and finding out about the exceptional work done to conserve them.ldquoBy opening now, our charity can start to make up for some of the income that wersquove lost this year, though this will not be enough to cover the charitable funds wersquove missed out on during the lockdown.ldquoPlease, come, and see and enjoy these properties again andyou can, I urge you to donate to the Trust to help make sure these places can be cared for and visited for generations to come.Full details can be found on the NTS website here.

title: galashiels-man-appointed-uk-ambassador-ireland
story: A GALASHIELS man has been appointed asBritains ambassador to Ireland.Paul Johnston, , was educated at St Margarets Primary School and Galashiels Academy.He has now been chosen for the role of Her Majestys Ambassador to Ireland, taking over from Robin Barnett.Mr Johnston joined the civil service in  and is a former UK ambassador to Sweden.More recently, he served as the UKs representative to NATO and to the European Unions political and security committee.Mr Johnston has also held diplomatic posts in New York and Paris.He still has family based in Galashiels, with his mother Muriel connected to Gala Opera and brother Alan a coach at Gala rugby club.Mr Johnston, who is married to Nicola, takes up his new appointment in September.

title: borders-teacher-retires-four-decades---ive-loved-it
story: A BORDERS teacher has retired after four decades in the classroom.Jessie Learmonth, , has worked in schools across the region.She said: "I think I always wanted to be a teacher ndash my sister said I was born a teacher."Mrs Learmonth, who lives in Ashkirk, moved to Hawick High School with her husband Peter in , following work at Blackburn Academy, West Lothian.After a year and a half in her temporary post in Hawicks PE department, Mrs Learmonth started working in general supply, where she taught science, maths, English, business and French."I drew the line at German ndash too dficult," she told the Border .In , Mrs Learmonth took a step back from teaching to raise her family.But once her three children were older, she retrained as a primary school teacher.Mrs Learmonth spent the last  and a half years teaching at Trinity Primary School, Hawick, where she taught pupils from P to P."Ive loved it ndash its a very special school," said Mrs Learmonth.During the coronavirus pandemic, Mrs Learmonth worked in the local hubs where she was able to see some colleagues and a small number of pupils.But due to the lockdown, Mrs Learmonth has not been able to truly celebrate her retirement with colleagues or say a proper goodbye to her pupils.She said: "Ill go back into the school."Im hoping staff from all years will be able to come, a lot of my ex-colleagues have retired too."In the meantime, Mrs Learmonth has plans to occupy herself with gardening, tidying her home and spending time with her two grandchildren.She added: "I enjoy crafts, puzzles, gardening."And I wont have any excuses for not having the time."

title: phase-3-fm-very-hopeful-lockdown-easing-week----changes
story: NICOLA Sturgeon says she is ldquovery hopeful that Scotland can enter Phase  of the four-part route map out of coronavirus lockdown this week.The First Minister is set to reveal the easing of more COVID- restrictions on Thursday, which would come into force the following day.Among the changes pencilled-in for the latest round of changes are the reopening of hairdressers, indoor pubs and being able to meet more loved ones indoors.What did the First Minister say During yesterdayrsquos daily coronavirus briefing in Edinburgh, Ms Sturgeon said: "I am, at this stage, very hopeful well be able to go into Phase . Theres nothing to suggest that will not be the case."That does not mean everything that was pencilled-in in the route map originally for phase three will happen in Phase ."And it certainly doesnt mean everything will happen immediately in Phase  - we may well take a phased approach, within the phase, as we have done with Phase ."So people should wait until weve concluded that assessment and then announce the outcome of that on Thursday."What is likely to change and when Last month, the First Minister set out some lsquoindicativersquo dates for the easing of lockdown in Scotland ndash including a number of dates included in Phase .This is reliant on a continued suppression of the virus across the country.Here, we detail out those changes:From July :Meeting indoors:From this date, households can meet indoors with a maximum of two other households ndash provided they maintain physical distancing.This will be the first time for many that they have been able to meet anyone indoors since lockdown began ndash with the exception to that being the lsquoextended householdsrsquo which were formed last month.Meeting outdoors:People can meet outdoors in extended groups with physical distancing.Two-metre rule:From this date, areas such as hospitality, shopping and public transport can reduce the two-metre rule to one-metrendash provided a number of mitigations are put in place.For the general public, however, the two-metre rule will remain the benchmark.From July :Shopping:Non-essential retail shops inside shopping centres can reopen.Outdoor sports:Organised outdoor contact sports can resume for children and young people.Dentists:All dental practices will begin to see registered patients for non-aerosol routine care.From July :Indoor hospitality:Pubs and restaurants can reopen indoors subject to physical distancing and hygiene rules.Hairdressers: Hairdressers and barbers can finally reopen from this date.Other indoor leisure: Cinemas, museums, galleries and libraries can open from this date ndash but with precautionary measures in place ndash including buying tickets online in advance.,params: .pushCinemas can reopen from July WhatI am shielding The above changes do not apply to people who have been advised to shield ndash their advice remains to do so until July .However, the First Minister did recently announce that outdoor exercise and meeting people from another householdis allowed provided strict physical distancing is followed.Ms Sturgeon said they will ldquocontinue to review the evidence leading up to July  and will refine the advice once recommended by clinicians.What  might change The First Minister also outlined a number of potential changes in Phase  ndash but added they are ldquounlikely to be in place before July .This includes the easing of restrictions on attendance at funerals, marriages and civil partnerships ndash provided physical distancing remains in place.Places of worship can also reopen for congregational services, with communal prayer allowed.Universities and colleges can also open with a phasedwith a blended model of remote and on-campus learning.And non-essential offices and call centres can reopen following the implementation of relevant guidance ndash with working from home and working flexibly remaining the default.Live events, indoor gyms, other personal retail services and other indoor entertainment venues such as nightclubs and theatres will be ldquosubject to further public health advice.

title: everyone-get-500-shopping-voucher-uk-government-scheme
story: EVERYONE in the UK could be given a pound shopping voucher under new proposals to help kickstart the economy after the coronavirus lockdown.Itrsquos thought the plans could encourage the public to begin spending local again ndash creating cash flow for businesses worst hit by the pandemic.The idea was drawn up by thinktank the Resolution Foundation ndash who suggest a one-year time limit for spending the money.What is the idea Under the scheme, every adult would be handed pound and every child given pound ndash with the payments restricted to lsquoface-to-facersquo retail and hospitality, instead of online.They would be universal, delivered as coupons, smartcards or even redeemable using mobile phones.The one-off paymentswould cost the UK Government around poundbillion.Its hoped the scheme could boost retail sectors post-lockdownWhy is it needed James Smith, at the Resolution Foundation, said there has been ldquohuge implications for sectors like retail, tourism and leisure.He said: ldquoThat is why the jobs of so many workers in these sectors are in the firing line. The Chancellorrsquos recovery package on Wednesday should reflect this unique economic challenge."As well as setting out the biggest ever peacetime job support programme, the Chancellor should get Britain spending in places where itrsquos needed most."A universal lsquoHigh Street Voucherrsquo scheme ndash worth pound per adult and pound per child ndash to be spent only in these sectors would kickstart demand in the right parts of our economy, boost living standards and deliver targeted support to the businesses that need help the most."The Chancellor has already shown that big, bold measures like the Job Retention Scheme are welcome and necessary in the current economic climate. He should take this same approach as we enter the crucial recovery phase of the crisis."You can view the full plans here.Will it happen ndash and when The UK Government has yet to comment on the plans.Official word could come as early as tomorrow, when Chancellor Rishi unveils new measures to protect the economy ndash however he has so far refused to speculate on whether the scheme could be implemented.He is expected to announce additional support for trainee and apprenticeship schemes, as well as a stamp duty ldquoholiday to support the housing industry.

title: youtube-cook-excited-borders-book-festival-debut
story: COOKING sensation Suzanne Mulholland canrsquot believe her luck at being a guest at the Borders Book Festival.Itrsquos an event the Ettrick Valley resident has attended for years.Mrs Mulholland, , is now excited about gracing the festivalrsquos virtual stage with her book The Batch Lady, a name by which she is possibly more famously known.She started her YouTube channel nearly three years ago, using it to share the benefits of what is known as batch cooking ndash a practice many householders know very well as they juggle work, childcare and home management.Her social media channels now have more than , followers, and she has appeared in the pages of The Sunand Daily Mail, as well as on ITVrsquos This Morning.But lockdown has seen her following grow even further, as shopping and cooking habits have changed, and the necessity to be canny with food has grown.ldquoBatch cooking is really prevalent at the moment, says Mrs Mulholland, ldquobased on everybodyrsquos shopping habits all of a sudden changing.ldquoPeople are shopping less and buying more, so gone are the days when people were shopping maybe every two to three days, nipping in and grabbing stuff.ldquoNow, people are going once a week, for a weekly shop. Wersquore seeing the amount that theyrsquore spending increasing, and theyrsquore buying a lot more but less often.Mrs Mulholland believes this trend will continue for some time, while shopping remains ldquoa feat.She says: ldquoYou have to stand in the queue outside, and wait your turn, and yoursquove got to think about the person standing two metres behind youhellipldquoEverybody all of a sudden needs to be a bit more organised and think in advance before they arrive at the shop.And with this decrease in shopping trips alongside a rise in the amount of groceries bought, there comes the quandary of use-by dates.ldquoThe sell-by dates nowadays are quite short, Mrs Mulholland says. ldquoTheyrsquore not allowing that your chicken is going to last to the end of the week, so itrsquos getting some of those meals prepped and put in the freezer, so come the end of the week, you can pull it out and itrsquos as fresh as the day you bought it.ldquoThe Batch Lady was set up, says Mrs Mulholland, with the aim of helping busy, working people ndash who either love cooking or hate it ndash to avoid the drudgery of producing daily family meals by preparing in advance.And she lives by this method herself. With the local shop a -minute drive away, Mrs Mulholland spends just half an hour in the shop itself, picking up her ingredients, ing home to cook the weekrsquos meals in roughly an hour, then freezing them and pulling one out each evening.Itrsquos a method that comes naturally to the business graduate and former time-management trainer.ldquoIrsquom about being very organised and getting mundane tasks done," she says. "Itrsquos always been my ethos. When I found myself on a rural farm [with husband Peter and children Jake, , and Zara, ], I realised that quite a lot of those things that I was teaching in a corporate environment resonated in the home le.,params: .pushAnd having answered her mum friendsrsquo requests to put her skills up on YouTube, she then got a call from HarperCollins offering a book deal ndash and the exciting opportunity to join her favourite book festival.Mrs Mulhollandrsquos three-book deal saw the first, The Batch Lady, published in March this year the second will be published next year but, in the meantime, her publisher suggested what would help in lockdown would be a ldquoplanner book ndash The Batch Lady Meal Planner ndashout on July .The book features  recipes, and guidance on how to meal plan and record manage freezer contents.And itrsquos the book she will share at this yearrsquos book festival, albeit online rather than in person.ldquoI was gutted, because the Borders Book Festival I go to every year ndash itrsquos right near my house, says Mrs Mulholland.ldquoI never miss it ndash Irsquove got a four-day ticket usually. And I was desperate to go to it, so Irsquom now doing the online version.ldquoItrsquos really special. I was so pleased to be an author finally and to be going to it as an author.The festival is not the only event Mrs Mulholland will be guesting at this year but it is the most important to the local YouTube star.ldquoThe Borders Book Festival was at the top of my list because itrsquos my local one."Itrsquos always so amazing that we have all these big authors come to the Borders, so that was why I really wanted to be in it. Irsquom a Borders girl!The video and live chat will be available on the Borders Book Festivals website at pm on July .

title: alexander-hamilton-scottish-roots-disney-sensation
story: HE is remembered in history as one of the Founding Fathers of the United States and, more recently, his story has been brought to le in a Broadway show.Butdid you know Alexander Hamilton, the face of the  bill, could trace his family history back to a castle ruin on the outskirts ofStevenston, North Ayrshire George Washingtons right hand man and the inspiration behind one of the most successful shows of all-time has been thrust back into the spotlightin recent days after Lin-Manuel Mirandas musical made its way onto streaming service Disney+.During his le, Hamilton became an influential interpreter and promoter of theU.S. Constitution, as well as the founder of the politys financial system, theFederalist Party, theUnited States Coast Guard, and theNew York Postnewspaper.George WashingtonAs the firstSecretary of the Treasury, Hamilton was the main author of the economic policies of Washingtons administration.He played a crucial role in laying the foundations of the America we know today, before he was shot dead at just the age byAaron Burr in a duel.At this point you might be wondering what exactly this has to do with Scotland Well,it doesnt take long for Hamiltons Scottish roots to be mentioned in the eponymous show, which opens: "How does a b****d, orphan, son of a w***e , and a Scotsman, dropped in the middle of a forgotten spot in the Caribbeanby providence, impoverished, in squalor, grow up to be a hero and a scholar "Hamilton, son of a Scotsman from Ayrshire, grew up on the West Indian island of Nevis . Given the lyrics to the shows opening, youve probably already guessed he had to endure a dficult upbringing.His father, James Hamilton, was the fourth son of the Laird of Grange, also named Alexander. He moved to the Caribbean instead of pursuing an education at the University of Glasgow like his brothers.It was there, itrsquos thought, on January , , that his son Alexander was born, though the date is uncertain. Some scholars believe it was two years later.It was a birth out of wedlock, explaining a later remark from President John Adams, who once described him as ldquothe b*****d brat of a Scottish peddler. His father had an affair with Rachel Fawcett Lavien, who was of British and French Huguenot descent.It was to be a troubled childhood. His parents had a dficult relationship, though it lasted many years ndash he had a brother born two years before him. His father deserted the family forcing Hamilton to take his first job at the age of  to help make ends meet. The death of his mother left him abandoned and orphaned aged just  in .Taken in by an older relative and thereafter by a local merchant, the young man soon began to excel in commerce and trade. Such was his evident talent that businessmen soon pooled funds to send him to America for an education.,params: .pushHe made swt progress in the US, devoting time to writing about politics. One report says he left the college he was attending to report on the Boston Tea Party, the first big revolt against the British.Alexander Hamilton is regarded as one of Americas Founding Fathers By  hersquod garnered many battle honours and attained the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. This brought him to the attention of Washington, who appointed him his assistant and trusted adviser.After the war, he graduated in law and commenced practice at the Bar in New York where he was a prominent figure. However, it was in politics and government that he was to excel and leave his real legacy. Influential in the drafting of the US Constitution, he was a delegate for New York and wrote the Federalist Papers.He remains the arch Federalist in the arguments that have raged on down through the years between state and federal rights.When Washington was elected President, he appointed Hamilton First Secretary of the Treasury.Plenty more was still to come for the lad with Ayrshire in his blood, until he was killed by Burr in .His legacy, however, lives on in wallets across America and TV screens around the world.

title: everyone-scotland-can-get-free-pint-tennents-next-week
story: EVERYONE of drinking age in Scotland can get a free pint of lager from Tennentrsquos to mark the reopening of pubs across the country.Hundreds of thousands of complimentary pints of Tennentrsquos Lager and Tennentrsquos Light will be waiting at  premises across the country.It comes as beer gardens welcome visitors after  weeks of lockdown and bars could reopen with social distancing on July .Kenny Gray, managing director at Tennentrsquos, said: ldquoFor the last  years, Tennentrsquos Lager has been dedicated to Scotland and proud to serve the freshest, quality pints to pubs and drinkers across the country.ldquoFrom moments with friends and family to birthdays, holidays, anniversaries and graduations, the list of things wersquove all missed during this dficult period is endless and we know that going to the pub ranks highly.ldquoAfter work drinks, cosy pub lunches and memorable nights out with friends have all been put on hold for nearly four long months.ldquoBut we can now finally look forward to celebrating these important milestones once again while creating new ones ndash and what better way to welcome everyone back than by dedicating a pint of Tennentrsquos Lager or Tennentrsquos Light to Scotland How can I claim my pint Drinkers can claim online atTennentsdedicatedtoyou.#

title: take-rubbish-home-scots-beauty-spots-swamped-litter-lockdown-eases
story: Scots are being urged to help avoid selfish, irresponsible behaviour which has seen beauty spots across the country swamped with litter and human waste as lockdown restrictions ease.Government agencies, campaigners and environmental experts have come together to issue a joint plea for people to act responsibly as restrictions ease further throughout Scotland.In the last few weeks, Scots have been allowed to venture further from their homes as part of the Scottish Governments route map out of lockdown.But some tourist hotspots have seen their landscapes and environments marred by a barrage of litter and human waste.Forestry and Land Scotland has reminded members of the public that while many car parks and beauty spots are now open, waste collection services may not be operational.Chief executiveSimon Hodgson said:ldquoAs Scotland gets re-accustomed to travelling further afield for leisure pursuits, we are appealing to the public to help avoid repeats of the selfish, irresponsible behaviour that over the past few weeks has seen many sites swamped by litter ndash or even despoiled by human waste.ldquoThis sort of anti-social behaviour not only creates a signicant health hazard but also eats in to the limited resources that land managers have at their disposal.ldquoWe would urge people to first of all think carefully about their travel plans, and secondly to behave like people who are proud to be able to call such a beautul country home: donrsquot visit sites until they are open and take your litter home.Mr Hodgson added:ldquoThe sad thing is, many of the people responsible for the littering would say they were proud to live in Scotland, and yet as we have seen over the past few weeks, they treat our beautul countryside in this contemptible manner. Itrsquos not acceptable.The call has been backed by Zero Waste Scotland, Keep Scotland Beautul, Scottish Water, Loch Lomond  The Trossachs National Park Authority, Scottish Natural Heritage and Cairngorms National Park Authority.Recent incidents have seen people charged after damaging national parks and culpable and reckless conduct across Scotland.Between Friday, July  and Sunday, July , more than  people were chargedwith breaches of the Loch Lomond andTheTrossachs National Park Camping Management Bylaws.Broken glass, bin bags of rubbish and sleeping bags were left littered across the park.In some areas, irreparable fire damage was caused to trees and the ground.Nineteen bags of litter were collected from a single site, with another site wielding a further ten.Iain Gulland, chief executive atZero Waste Scotland, said: ldquoWith limited access available to activities and facilities, our areas of beauty are more important than ever before for people to enjoy some exercise and fresh air."We are fortunate to live in such a wonderful country and ask people not to spoil the enjoyment of everyone .ldquoPeople who litter are committing a criminal offence, are often risking our safety and polluting our environment."There are no excuses - you take it out with you, bin it or take it home when you are done.

title: major-changes-scotlands-shielding-population-week----need-know
story: THE Health Secretary has today revealed the easing of measures for people shielding in Scotland during lockdown.Initially, the Scottish Government asked people to shield until July  but stated that there would be periodical easing of restrictions throughout July.But during the daily coronavirus briefing today, Jeane Freeman confirmed a number of changes ndash which will take place from Friday.What will change From Friday, those who are shielding will no longer require to distance themselves from those they live with.Those in single-parent households or who live on their own will also be able to form an extended household group in the same way as the rest of the population can, including being able to visit someone in their home or stay overnight without having to socially distance.Ms Freeman also said that those who are in this category will also be able to book holiday accommodation or go to a second home, provided these do not have shared facilities with other households.However, the Health Secretary ldquostrongly advised that this is only done with people in the same household or as part of an extended household.The Health Secretary also said that those who are shielding will be able to meet up with people from two households outdoors, in the same way as the rest of the population, as well as go inside to use the toilet.What did the Health Secretary say #Ms Freeman said: ldquoI hope the changes that we have announced and those that I hope will continue to come will help to ease what I know has been an extraordinary burden that shielding has placed on you over the past few months.ldquoI canrsquot say enough to express how grateful I am to you for following the advice. It has been stressful, I know at times it has felt frightening and I know at times it has felt restrictive.ldquoRight now we can begin to ease those restrictions because of the falling infection rate. Right nowyou follow these precautions our clinical advisers tell us that the risk of you catching the virus is low ndash that is very dferent from the beginning of the pandemic, as well you know.ldquoI hope that you are able to resume much more of your lives than you have been advised to be able to do in the last few months.Letters will be sent to people in the shielding category from Thursday, Ms Freeman said.

title: nicola-sturgeon-reacts-border-telegraph-investigation
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has spoken about the Border rsquosinvestigation into patient transfers during the coronavirus pandemic.NHS Borders moved dozens of hospital patientsinto care homes without checking whether the patients had COVID-.The health board was not breaching Scottish Government guidance at the time.Asked about the transfers, the First Minister said it is ldquoimportant to note that NHS Bordersbelieves the transfers did not spread the virus.Ms Sturgeon also criticised Borders MP John Lamont for his accusationthat the transfers show ldquohow negligent the SNP were on care homes.When that allegation was put to her, the SNP leader said: ldquoPart of me wants to treat that comment with the contempt it deserves.Ms Sturgeonrsquos comments came during her televised press conference today , with ITV Borderrsquos political editor Peter MacMahon among the journalists posing questions.Mr MacMahon asked Ms Sturgeon to comment on this newspaperrsquos report - based on a Freedom of Information [FoI] request - that  Borders patients had been transferred to care homes without being tested before April .The First Minister said: ldquoIrsquove not seen the Border or the particular FoI so Irsquoll not comment too much on the detail of that.However, Ms Sturgeon did respond to Mr Lamontrsquos criticism of her government.She said the Toryrsquos remarks were ldquoan attempt to politicise something that is inappropriate".Going on to defend her handling of the pandemic response in Scotland, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoWe had very dficult decisions to make.ldquoWe took those decisions on the best knowledge and evidence we had at the time."And wersquove had in place lots of things to protect care home residents.She added: ldquoThe death toll in care homes - and the death toll overall - has been awful and I would be the first person to acknowledge that and there will be lessons that we all have to learn from that.ldquoAnybody trying to make this an issue of party-politics should really take a long, hard look at themselves in the mirror.

title: make-diy-face-mask-using-just-t-shirt-hair-bobbles
story: FACE coverings are to become mandatory across all shops in Scotland as of tomorrow.Following the move to make the coverings compulsory on public transport, the First Minister argued that"as we all start to interact more, it is vital that we take all reasonable steps to reduce risk."And we know that these coveringscan help reduce the risk of transmission indoors."To help people along with the process, the Scottish Government has released a handy video on how to make your own face mask - using just a hair bobble or rubber band and a T-shirt.Watch how to make your own DIY mask below:From Friday  July, you will be required by law to wear a face covering when you go into a shop. Face coverings are already mandatory on all public transport.Some exemptions apply, which you can read about at https:t.co uCivwyYlLearn how to make your own ## pic yGmXylLrmdash Scottish GovernmentJuly , How will it be enforced The First Minister said the rules will be enforced in a similar way to those on public transport.She said it would be "not fair or reasonable" to expect shop workers to enforce the rules - and instead it would be down to the police to do so.Fixed penalty notices - which start at pound - could be handed out by the police, but she says they will do so only at a last resort.Ms Sturgeon added: "All of us can help by doing this voluntarily because it can make a dference".Who is exempt Children under five will be exempt from this rule, Ms Sturgeon confirmed, along with those with certain medical conditions.Following in line with the public transport rules, then the following groups may also be exempt:Police officers first responders in an emergencyStaff separate by a physical barrier ndash including bus drivers behind a screenAnyone with ahealthcondition where a mask would cause dficulty, including asthmaYou need to take medicationTo speak with someone who lip readsWhen asked to remove it by a relevant authority, e.g. Police officer.But Ms Sturgeonsaid: ldquoFor everyone , face coverings will be mandatory."What  was announced From tomorrow,the two-metre social distancing rule can be reduced in the hospitality and retail sectors and on public transport at that time.Pubs, restaurants and shops will be allowed to adhere to a one-metre rule instead, with mitigation measures in place.But the general rule in law will be that businesses must take reasonable measures to ensure two-metre distancing is maintained, Ms Sturgeon said.

title: buy-scottish-island-iconic-loch-lomond-inchconnachan-island-goes-sale
story: During lockdown, some Scots have been basking in the opportunity to enjoy some much needed alone time.Now, those enjoying the solitude can take their privacy one step further with an entirely private Scottish island all to themselves.An island off the western shore of southern Loch Lomond is to be launched on the market, boasting private, secluded bays and ancient woodland.Inchconnachanhas been in the ownership of the Colquhoun family since the th century but uninhabited for the last  years.Now, it is set to go on the market for offers of more than pound,.The island is only accessible by boat from the shores of Luss, andis home to some of the best wildle the country has to offer.Inchconnachanrsquos ancient oak woodland and secluded bays attract otters and deer, along with a wide iety of birds including the endangered capercaillie and the occasional pair of nesting ospreys.The island is both an Area of Special Scientic Interest and a Special Area of Conservation as well as being part of the Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park.Surrounded by a beautul backdrop of mountain ranges, including Ben Lomond, the island is currently home to a derelict Colonial-style timber bungalow dating from the s, reputedly built by retired tea merchant Admiral Sullivan in the style of an Indian tea plantation bungalow.Butyou want a little more luxury, planning consent and detailed architectural drawings have been obtained to replace the existing bungalow with a new four-bedroom lodge and one-bedroom wardenrsquos house, along with a boathouse and pier.Cameron Ewer for Savills said: ldquoThis is an extraordinary opportunity to acquire a beautul and completely private, yet accessible, retreat and create a wonderful new residence there."For those seeking peace and seclusion, yet wanting all that this part of Scotland has to offer in the way of nature and water-based sport and activities, this is surely the ultimate prize.Tom Stewart-Moore for Knight Frank said: ldquoTo be able to build your own house on your own private island but yet in a very accessible and beautul part of the country will be a dream for many and is likely to have global appeal.

title: borders-recycling-centres-need-know-july-13
story: RECYCLING centres will ditch their number-plate entry system on Monday .During lockdown, sites in the Borders had restricted access to drivers depending on whether their number plate has an odd or even number.But Scottish Borders Councilhas announced it is dropping the system, extending opening hours and accepting kerbside rubbish.From Monday, the centres will open at am on weekdays and close at .pm, with weekends am-.pm.As was the case before the pandemic, the sites will be closed on one day a week .SBC chief executive Tracey Logan said: "We are now at a stage where the majority of waste types are being accepted. ldquoThe next step as part of the phased recovery is to change the operating hours back to what they were before lockdown."This will increase the number of hours sites are open each day.ldquoIt will also signicantly reduce the number of staff that are required to support the current operating model.ldquoThis will assist the councils wider recovery plan allowing support staff toto their normal jobs."All sites will close between .pm and pm to allow staff to take a lunch break.Some regulations will remain in place, including: a maximum of five bags of waste at a time are to be brought to any centre only one person per household should travel to a recycling centre and no trailers or horse-boxes will be accepted.Opening hours are as follows:Weekdays:middot Morning: .am - .pmmiddot Afternoon: .pm - .pmWeekend:middot Morning: .am - .pmmiddot Afternoon: .pm - .pmWeekday closures:middot Duns - Thursdaymiddot Eshiels- Wednesdaymiddot Eyemouth - Tuesday and Fridaymiddot Galashiels - Tuesdaymiddot Hawick - Wednesdaymiddot Kelso - Mondaymiddot Selkirk - Monday and Friday

title: ryanair-virgin-among-worst-travel-firms-refunds-coronavirus
story: Virgin, Love Holidays and Ryanair are some of the worst travel firms for offering holiday refunds during the coronavirus pandemic, according to a survey forMoneySavingExpert.Brits were essentially banned from travelling abroad for over  days, meaning many people had to cancel their holiday plans.During this time, millions of people have been owed refunds for holidays they couldnrsquot go on - but the MoneySavingExpery survey suggests that not every travel firm has treated their customers the same.Results of the surveyThe survey ran between  June and  July and received , responses. The aim was to find out how people felt about their lsquorefund experiencersquo and whether they actually got one.Three big names did particularly poorly. Ryanair scoredthe worst of the major brands with a net score of -%. It wasjoined by Virginand Love Holidays .Unsurprisingly these three firms were also among the worst in refunding with just % of Ryanair, Virgin Holidays and Love Holidays customers saying they hadreceived a refund to date.A majority of Virgin Atlantic and Ryanair customers said they hadbeen waiting more than two months for a refund since first asking.Alpharooms was rated the overall worst for customer experience and refunds, with a net score of -%. Not one of customers surveyed said they received a refund.However, not every travel firm has performed badly during the pandemic.A total of % of Jet and Jet Holidays customers who had bookings cancelled said theyreceived a refund.Trailfinders and Airbnb customers were also likely to get a refund, with % and % respectively saying they hadbeen refunded.lsquoIt is time for regulators and politicians to take actionrsquoMartin Lewis, founder ofMoneySavingExpert,has been outspoken about the refund issue throughout the pandemic.He said that the ldquorefund farce and has left people in distress and ldquosome have seen their mental health impacted by it.He added: "It is time for regulators and politicians to take action.ldquoEven now, after months, less than a third of people in our mammoth survey have received the fulllegally required refunds, and it simply isnrsquot good enough.ldquoWe will be passing a dossier on this to the Competition and Markets Authority , Civil Aviation Authority and Department for Transport."Of course, we understand the impact of the pandemic on the travel industry sector is devastating. Itrsquos why Irsquove long called for forbearance both ways ndashpeople can help by taking vouchers or rebooking then they should."Yet how inidual firms have treated their customers during this time will long be remembered.
